title: There's No Stopping Her!
subtitle: Noreen Hannington, a grandmother working at a garage

cards.text:
Noreen Hannington, a sixty-three-year-old grandmother of five, arrives at the Tyre and Wheel Company in North London at 8 a.m. every morning. She puts on a greasy apron, rolls up her sleeves and gets ready for the day's work.

The first customer pulls up in an old van. It has a flat tyre and the driver was lucky to make it to the garage. Noreen puts on her rubber gloves and gets down to work. She casually pulls off the wheel, swings it onto the work bench with one hand and takes it apart. 'There's your problem, sir,' she announces, pointing at a tiny hole in the tyre. Right now, he couldn't care less about that, since what he feels is more serious: a fast-decreasing sense of his own worth. At least his mates haven't come to witness him being rescued by a sweet-faced granny!
cards.question: How does the van driver feel after getting help from Noreen?
choices: Impressed by the way she works
Embarrassed that he needed it
Relieved at finding it in time
Unconvinced by her advice
cards.highlight: a fast-decreasing sense of his own worth

cards.text: Why is Noreen in this line of work, anyway? It's a family business and when Noreen's husband died, she decided to keep it going for her two sons, Bill and Fred, then aged only seventeen and fifteen. Before that, her husband had let her watch what went on in the garage, but she had never been allowed to lift a finger. Initially, she doubted her ability to make a go of it, but somehow she managed, and although the boys are now grown up, has never got round to handing over.
cards.question: Why did Noreen take over the running of the business?
choices: To fulfil a promise to her husband
To stop her sons fighting over it
To make sure it stayed in the family
To prove that she could manage it
cards.highlight: keep it going for her two sons

cards.text: Now the business has expanded to include not only the sons but daughters-in-law, too. With Noreen in charge, it all runs smoothly. 'Bill handles anything mechanical. Fred does electrical repairs, while I fix flat tyres and anything else to do with wheels.' She waves at the new computer: 'I also do the accounts. They keep on at me to think modern, but we don't need this.' Bill jokes: 'We don't need you, but you're still here!'
cards.question: 'Keep on at' in line 34 describes a way of:
choices: Trying to make someone laugh
Trying to accept something
Trying to convince someone
Trying to make something easier
cards.highlight: They keep on at me to think modern

cards.text: Noreen is indeed still around, lifting well over twelve kilogrammes in weight up to twenty times a day, which is rather surprising, to say the least. As Bill says, 'Tyre changing's hard and she shouldn't be doing it.' Noreen pulls a face and replies, 'I'll stop when I'm eighty-five. Anyway, it was far worse in the old days, when there was less equipment.' 'And before that, you were repairing the horses and carts,' jokes Bill. We all laugh at that one.
cards.question: The writer finds it strange that:
choices: Bill allows his mother to work at her age.
Noreen knows exactly when she will retire.
Bill doesn't find a way to help his mother.
Noreen does a job that is unsuitable for her
cards.highlight: lifting well over twelve kilogrammes in weight up to twenty times a day, which is rather surprising

cards.text: Suddenly it all becomes obvious to me â€“ these friendly jokes create an environment that Noreen loves and, despite her advanced age, she wants to stick it out, even if the work is hard at times. So much so, that on the rare occasions when she does go away, she can't wait to return. 'I have just had a wonderful holiday on board a cruise ship. Going to sea made sure I couldn't come running back to the garage after a few hours! But walking back into the garage meant coming home to me,' she says fondly.
cards.question: Why, in the writer's opinion, does Noreen want to carry on working at the garage?
choices: She feels that working keeps her young.
She enjoys the working atmosphere
She feels genuinely interested in the work.
She looks forward to more expensive holidays.
cards.highlight: these friendly jokes create an environment that Noreen loves

cards.text: She stops talking for a moment to check the drinks machine. 'It's out of tea,' she shouts. Everybody sighs; on her first day back at work, the boss is making her presence felt.
cards.question: Why do Noreen's family sigh when she mentions the problem with the drinks machine?
choices: They don't feel responsible for it.
They wish they had noticed it first.
They think she's asking them to do it
They feel that she is being unreasonable.
cards.highlight: the boss is making her presence felt

cards.text: Surely all this heavy work must affect her health though? Noreen claims that it doesn't, though her daughter-in-law mentions recent back trouble. 'That had nothing to do with the tyres! It was when I was doing those stupid roof tiles,' says Noreen. 'We rebuilt the garage and added a first floor. It was quite a nice change to be a labourer for a while, actually.
cards.question: When Noreen hurt her back, she:
choices: wasn't able to go on with the building work.
missed her usual job of repairing the tyres.
blamed her injury on having to fix the tiles.
enjoyed her temporary change of job
cards.highlight: It was quite a nice change to be a labourer for a while, actually

cards.text: Noreen is a delightful woman, who clearly intends to be part of the business for a long time yet.
cards.question: Which phrase best describes the writer's view of Noreen?
choices: a determined woman
a demanding boss
a loving grandmother
a co-operative worker
cards.highlight: Noreen is a delightful woman, who clearly intends to be part of the business for a long time yet
